_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A?asco Filtration Plant recently begins operation, located at the State Road 109 kilometer 5.4 Interior, Bo. Espino, A?asco, Puerto Rico, 00610.  This water treatment plant is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.  PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program #3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine.  The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68.  The Prevention Program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.

Accidental Release:
It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and State applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason A?asco Filtration Plant has undergone some engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve security and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled.
A?asco Filtration Plant is located close to the area where the plants supply the potable water.  The chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans.

The chlorine is delivered from the PRASA Chlorine Warehouse and Distribution Center at Puerto Nuevo to the plant in one (1) ton containers.  A?asco Filtration Plant could have a storage maximum volume of 14,000 lbs distributed in seven (7) containers, only four containers are active.  The process begins on four containers scales, each containers are connected to mounted vacuum regulators (valves), the chlorine flows to a switchover valve and pass through a gas feeder to the injectors and then the chlorinated water sent two (2) different injections points along the process of the plant. 

Worst Case Scen

ario:
The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.  This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2,000 lbs) during 10 minutes and other specifications related to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected.  Using the Landview 6 Simulator and the US Census 2000, it was identified that 5,691 residents, a school and Hospital are inside the 1.3 miles radio.  No known environmental receptors (state parks, or official designated wildlife preserves) are located within this radio area.  The ALOHA Modeling Dispersion Program was used to simulate the gas dispersion.

Alternative Case Scenario:
The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2,000 lbs container, but throughout a pipe leak.  In the case the end point distance is calculated at 0.1 miles, 21 public receptors were identified over the most recent map.  Also no known environmental receptors are located within this radio area.

General Accident Release Prevention Program 
PRASA is actually in a very aggressive operation to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facility which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans.  Standard Operational Procedures (SOP?s) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the chlorine.  List of all SOP?s are indicated in the PSM report and are located in the plant.

Emergency Response Program:
PRASA has various SOP?s to manage emergency programs associated

to a release of the chemical and also related to the emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.

Five years Accident History:
The A?asco Filtration Plant has not reported any accident during the last five years, since it began operations a few months ago. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
A?asco Filtration Plant began recently a chlorination process with ton containers.  The facilities and equipment are new and include a vacuum operated system to improve the control of the process and the safety of the chlorine handling and storage.  Additional reinforcement of administrative activities related to containers handling and transportation, access control,  emergency personal protective equipment, preventive maintenance and audits is required. Recommendations were given on that regard on last PHA dated May 1, 2008.
